titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Kerby Miller Papers AIA.076
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-11-20T10:24-0500

change.item: Revised by Emma Sarconi to incorporate materials from accession 2015.051.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in 9 record cartons and 1 oversized flat box

did.abstract: Kerby A. Miller is a historian and Curators’ Professor at the University of Missouri. Miller graduated from Pomona College in 1966 and University of California, Berkley with an M.A. in 1967 and a Ph.D in 1976. His teaching and published work focuses on Irish history, often with an emphasis on social, immigration, and urban history. This collection consists of materials created or collected by Kerby Miller in the course of his research, teaching, and writing on Irish and Irish American history. Materials include photocopies of American Loyalists' petitions to the British government, a run of British Information Services news bulletins concerning conflict in Northern Ireland, and research materials created in the course of his academic scholarship, including original writings, reviews of his work, photocopied letters from Irish immigrants and citizens, and correspondence between Miller and other academics and institutions. Major subjects and themes present in these research files include pre- and post-immigration economic issues, experiences coming to and first impressions of living in America, genealogical records, and accounts of Irish family life.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist, but groupings of materials have been identified based on similar content and context of creation. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Kerby Miller, the creator of this collection, were relinquished and transferred to the public domain in 2015. These materials are governed by a Creative Commons CC0 license. Users need not secure permission from the Tamiment library to publish or reproduce materials in this collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Donated by Kerby Miller in April 2015. The accession number associated with this gift is 2015.018. An additional 8 boxes were donated in June of 2015 as accession 2015.051 and added as "Academic Research and Writing" series.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Kerby Miller Papers; AIA 076; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Archives of Irish America Irish Republicanism Papers (AIA 022)

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of materials created or collected by Kerby Miller in the course of his research, teaching, and writing on Irish and Irish American history. Materials include photocopies of American Loyalists' petitions to the British government, a run of British Information Services news bulletins concerning conflict in Northern Ireland, and research materials created in the course of his academic scholarship, including original writings, reviews of his work, photocopied letters from Irish immigrants and citizens, and correspondence between Miller and other academics and institutions. Major subjects and themes present in these research files include accounts of Irish family life, pre- and post-immigration economic issues, and experiences coming to and first impressions of living in America.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Collection was received with materials divided into distinct sets based on topic or type of material, with some materials loose and others in titled, alphabetized manila folders. Loose materials were rehoused in acid-free folders and boxes, and described by an archivist. Alphabetized and foldered photocopies of American loyalist petitions to the British government were kept in their original folders and in their original order.

An accretion was received in June 2015 and described in October of 2015, and incorporated into the collection as the series "Academic Research and Writing" based on its content and the context of its creation. These materials were rehoused in acid-free folders and boxes when necessary while keeping the folders in their original order. Folder titles were transcribed directly from original folders when necessary. Oversized materials were removed from their original order and rehoused in bigger boxes and folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Materials in this series include a copy of Nicholas Nolan’s 1933 Ph.D. thesis from University College Dublin titled “A Celtic Exodus, or the Irish Emigration”; photocopies of American Loyalists’ petitions during the British government during the American Revolutionary War asking for compensation for losses, explaining their political acts and affiliations, and describing their lives in America; and a run of British Information Services news bulletins on various aspects of the Troubles in Northern Ireland during the late 1980s and early 1990s.

did.unittitle: American Loyalist Petitions to the British Government

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Photocopies and related research material of Irish-born American Loyalists' petitions to the British government during the American Revolutionary War. In these letters, the writers ask for compensation for their losses, explaing their political acts and affiliations, and describe their lives in America (including their occupations and emigration history). Other documents include lists and indexes of claimants, as well as the determinations made by the Commission of Inquiry into the Losses and Services of the American Loyalists.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: Photocopies of this material was made from a microfilm collection entitled "American Loyalists: Transcripts of the Manuscript Books and Papers of the Commission of Inquiry into the Losses and Services of the American Loyalists" that was transcribed for the New York Public Library. The original records from which the microfilm collection was created are housed in the Public Record Office of England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Collection of weekly or bi-weekly bulletins produced by the British Information Services in New York City concerning the Troubles in the late 1980s and early 1990s. These bulletins acted as propangda policy briefs on various aspects of conflict in Northern Ireland, producing a directed message for media coverage consistent with official British diplomatic policy. Subjects that frequently appear in these bulletins include religion, electoral politics, employment discrimination, paramilitary funerals, law enforcement practices or regulations, and incidents of violence attributed to various Irish republican paramilitary groups, as well as dossiers of republican organizations such as Sinn Fein, the Official Irish Republican Army (IRA), the Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA or PIRA), and the Irish National Liberation Army (INLA). Also present are excerpts of statements made by officials or other prominent figures.

did.unittitle: Nolan, Nicholas. "A Celtic Exodus, or the Irish Emigration”

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Miller's research materials, original writings, and ephemera created in the course of his academic scholarship, including photocopied letters from Irish immigrants and citizens, correspondence between Miller and other academics and institutions, and response to and reviews of Miller's writings. Major subjects and themes present in the research notes and copies of primary source materials include genealogical records, accounts of Irish family life, pre- and post-immigration economic issues, and experiences coming to and first impressions of living in America.
